posts.name: Miss. Isrow
posts.cooked:
Trying to figure out if our climb would be counted. It is completely off the ground. I would count this as inconsequential but want to be sure! IMG_4699 4284√ó5712 4.05 MB

IMG_4699 4284√ó5712 4.05 MB

posts.name: Evan McDonald
posts.cooked:
If the robot touches any part of the I bolt, the chain, or the top of the cage, it‚Äôs illegal.

I‚Äôll find the exact rule in a minute, I don‚Äôt have it off the top of my head, but from the looks of this picture, this wouldn‚Äôt be legal since the elevator touches the chain.

Screenshot_20250226-203530 1080√ó625 117 KB

Screenshot_20250226-203530 1080√ó625 117 KB

Screenshot_20250226-203530 1080√ó625 117 KB

Most likely. The robot would be resting against the chain for an extended period of time.

image 1396√ó717 230 KB

image 1396√ó717 230 KB

image 1396√ó717 230 KB

posts.name: Max H.
posts.cooked: The closest interpretation would be by use of stabilization using the chain, however one may argue that it doesn‚Äôt contribute to the climb in any way

posts.name: Miss. Isrow
posts.cooked: That‚Äôs where my team is conflicted. The rule says ‚Äúrobot may not contact the anchors (anchors were previously defined as the top of the cage and the chain) exceptions are granted for actions that are inconsequential‚Äù. It might be considered stabilizing it - but I guess because our climber isn‚Äôt made to touch the chain I feel like it might be okay.
You want to make it obvious to the referees that you are not breaking the rules. The original post is not obviously not breaking the rules, and therefore is at a high risk of drawing the penalty.

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: I think it depends on whether the chain is actually supporting the robot or not. If it is, then that would be illegal, but id it‚Äôs just touching the chain i think it might be considered inconsequential, but I don‚Äôt think you should rely on that

posts.name: Evan McDonald
posts.cooked:
At that point it might be up to referee interpretation. If you can prove that the bot is touching without actually relying on the chain, you could maybe argue a case for it.

I would just shoot for the side of caution and see if you can find a way to make it not touch the bot, just to be safe.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
I would be careful with language like ‚Äúsupport‚Äù

Deflecting the chain has serious implications for how the center of mass relates to the frame of the robot and thus if bumpers or wheels are touching the ground - especially if the robot‚Äôs climb is close to the ground when complete.

For example, based on the amount of deflection in the OP image, it looks like the chain is doing a bit of stabilization, preventing the robot from tipping.

To the OP: See if you can grab the cage higher up with your existing lever arm length, which means you will not be pulling the chain into the elevator crossbrace when you finish your climb.

Another option may be to play with counterweights or seeing if you can move/ re-orientate the battery a bit (my guess is the battery is located opposite the elevator). You need to move the center of mass closer to the elevator.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
You are unlikely to get a penalty, but you also will not get climb points awarded.

Deflection of the chain is substantial contact, even if it‚Äôs not directly supporting the

posts.name: Miss. Isrow
posts.cooked: Thank you! Some of these came up in conversation with the kids - we just compete this Friday and were hoping to not have to fix anything lol. Overall consensus is better safe than sorry

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: It‚Äôs touching the Chain part of the Anchor. Park points only, irrespective of the penalty.

posts.name: GaryVoshol
posts.cooked:
G419 tells what you can‚Äôt do during the match. A ref would need to decide if contact was inconsequential or not.

Section 6.5.2 tells the criteria for CAGE points. It is evaluated 3 seconds after the match ends (well technically it could be before that if everything stops moving, but those cages will be swinging around for more than 3 seconds). At that point, the ROBOT cannot be touching any part of the ANCHOR.

So illegal? Maybe, maybe not - it depends on what the ref calls during the match. But getting points - definite no.

posts.name: Chris Cross
posts.cooked: I would definitely say that is a no-point climb. Not related to the OP, but you may also want to look more closely at your energy chain.  From the limited point of view of the picture posted above, it does not seem to be constrained correctly.  We had e-chain like this in 2018 that was unsupported and able to flop around.  It was nothing but trouble for us. The field crew had a special box that they collected parts in just from us.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: To fix this, I would recommend adding weight to the other end of the robot.  If you do that, it should hang differently, which will let you not contact the chain.

posts.name: Chris Herzog
posts.cooked:
Skyehawk:

Deflecting the chain has serious implications for how the center of mass relates to the frame of the robot and thus if bumpers or wheels are touching the ground - especially if the robot‚Äôs climb is close to the ground when complete.

For example, based on the amount of deflection in the OP image, it looks like the chain is doing a bit of stabilization, preventing the robot from tipping.

I‚Äôm 100% with @Skyehawk here - if you are actually deflecting the chain, it isn‚Äôt inconsequential contact because there are forces involved that are acting on the chain.

Touching but not deflecting the chain seems like a valid argument one could make.

If the chain contact was removed from the pic above, the robot would hang differently so I would not consider that ‚Äúinconsequential‚Äù contact.
